ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Regarding question 3 on out of class assignments = weekly reading commentaries and the final paper. I believe weekly reading commentaries contribute very little to learning. I did not like the selection of readings, much less having to comment on them. Some readings were too much theory. The final paper was very helpful to my learning.Regarding question 5 instructor responsiveness: students don't reach out to Dr. Pachauri, because he is not around during the week and he is too busy with his worklife to attend to student inquires. The TA had to fill in this gap.
The class content was really very basic. For a grad level course there should have been some advanced topics discussed. Very little new learning.
No further comments
The guest speakers were all very interesting, but instructor lectures didn't seem to go too deep.There was never much discussion of non-guest-speaker readings during lecture.
Guest lectures. Prof. Pachauri was able to bring in some of the top policy makers and scientists. It was a great experience being able to ask them candid questions. LOVED it.
Guest speakers were excellent.
Establishing a personal connection with Dr. Pachauri.
The instructor's ability to expound on a topic. It was also very relevant, engaging us with the biggest issues of our time and exposing us to some influential people.
Some of the guest speakers were quite good.
The guest speakers and the weekly readings. It was so cool to be able to listen to, and ask questions to Pachauri and the guest speakers. Having lunch provided after class was also a nice bonus.
External speakers were central to the success of the class.
The ability to interact with thought leaders and hear their candid opinions on the most salient issues of our time was incredibly rewarding.
The office hours with Patci. The discussions with the guest lecturers.
We had the opportunity to listen many Resource Persons of international repute.
The depth of the instructor´s explanations and the lecturers he brought.
the guest speakers

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Wish the course readings were more tied to class discussions. In terms of topics yes. But, we never really discussed the readings. Also, too many readings were assigned for each class.Even if the classes were only for about 6/8 weeks, it was a substantial amount of work. Especially with the final paper. Sometimes I felt like this was a 3 credit course except for the duration and work involved.
More clarity needed in syllabus regarding scheduling, due dates, and assignments. There was a lot of confusion.

The class invited guest speakers every week - however, quite often the speaker would just walk into the room and we would go straight into questions. I think the class needs to make sure students do background research on the speaker. This is not mandated in any way and it's up to students to go dig up the speaker's bio and accomplishments. It would be helpful to get a bit more guidance from the professor/TA on reading background materials about the speaker, so we know what to ask him. It seemed awkward for the speaker to just walk in, and for students to start asking questions without having had any kind of conversation on why this speaker was invited and what his/her expertise and professional accomplishments are.
It was taken for granted that many concepts may have been new to students. It was so cutting-edge that the background got overlooked.

Better communication and coordination with students in the class. There was confusion about when assignments were due and when we were having class. The grading scale for the weekly reading assignments was also confusing. Although certain criteria had been given for the assignments (length, spacing) it seemed like these criteria didn't matter. It was also a bit frustrating that students were graded on whether or not they asked questions in class, because the TA would compete for already valuable question time and ask questions to the speakers. If the TA wants to ask questions during lectures, don't grade students on whether they speak up or not. Pachauri's presentations were also really generic. Students already knew a lot about the topics he was presenting on, so we didn't really learn anything knew during his presentations.
Reading list could be much improved as there were many superfluous readings or readings that were simply not the best available.
This class needs to be a 1 credit course with reading and reading repsonces. The 20+ page paper at the end of the class was not need and did not add to my learning experience.
It should be made a full 3 credits course
Maybe more interaction between students and professor. The presentations of the final project was not very well organized, and the instructor was not there, only the TA.
instructor's lectures

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: I highly appreciated the detailed and thoughtful grading of commentaries.

Recognize that the TA had a lot of work in this class, more than other TAs in other classes.Many emails sent out throughout the semester, most of them were unclear and required additional clarifications which were confusing.Many versions of the syllabus with date and schedule changes that were hard to plan around.Comments on graded reading responses were contradictory and confusing:Example 1. When I wrote a response that was 2 pages, I was told to stick to the 1 page limit. For the next one, I stuck to 1 page and was told to expand my thoughts, it wasn't long or in-depth enough (you can only go so in-depth in 1 page double spaced). For the following one, I wrote 2.5 pages and received positive feedback.Example 2. In one response, I talked too much about the readings. In the next response, which was fairly similar in terms of my mention of the readings and my own thoughts/analysis, I got good feedback.
TA was fairly available to provide guidance with final paper.

Prof is too busy/uninterested in actually connecting with and teaching students. The TA was left to administer the entire class, and seemed to start to think that she herself was a professor. She graded our one page "reading responses" as if there were expected to be of publishable quality and to contain entirely novel analyses and perspectives on climate change. No one on the planet can accomplish that in one page. Expectations for the 20 page final paper were exceedingly unclear. And that assignment itself was far too substantial for a two credit class. This was a heavier work load than most 3 credit classes. I didn't take a course with the head of the IPCC to do a huge independent research project. He needed to be more involved and invested in the class. I doubt he'll even read our final papers.
Jasmine was accessible and responsive.
The TA never got back to me immediately over email, but she would respond within a few days.

The TA was not clear with here expectations and keep changing things after the start of the class. I think we had 5 updated syllabus running into October. She often responded to emails with see the syllabus but the syllabus did not have clear answers.
It was nice and appreciable
I was under the impression that the instructor was not very available, although the TA was very helpful.
both were available and helpful

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It covers the whole breadth of topics that I'm interested in.
The course material would be helpful to every student at F&ES.
Climate change is the priority international agenda. I feel with an exposure as we had in this course, Masters in Environment Management is better justified in my case.

Sustainable development, climate change and energy are key issues to my interest. This class has provided very detailed information as well as generic, and I have been able to use the information from this class in other classes and projects.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was looking forward to hearing Dr. Pachauri and his guests lecture.
B/c it was taught by the Chairman of the IPCC.
The area is one I was interested in and the pre-eminence of the instructor was alluring.
Because Pachauri was the instructor and because students would be able to interact with him and the guest speakers.
I feel it is one of the most important courses for MEM and especially with a faculty of international repute like Prof Pachauri.

Because I thought it would offer a generic overview of climate change and sustainable development, which are topics very interesting for me. The instructor´s experience and international recognition also attracted me to take this class.
for the opportunity to learn from Dr. Pachauri

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: I was pleased with the selection of speakers. Some shared innovative and challenging thoughts.I am largely disappointed with the part of the class taught by Dr. Pachauri. In fact, he is not in a position to teach. The reason for this is that given his appointment as Chairman of the IPCC, his opinions and messages in class are much too conservative. This is just like every public speech that I have heard him give - he is unable to be provocative and to truly speak his mind - he must be "careful" in what he says (as if there was always a journalist in the room). This leaves me disappointed, feeling like he needs to push the envelope and say things as they are, rather than saying them in politically correct and cautious ways.
No.

Not quite. The readings never got discussed in the class in depth. We don't know what our peers responses were so no learning there. The class presentations were very superficial and did not delve deep into the fascinating complexities of sustainable development. The speakers were good though, but for that there was no need to take the class.

Yes and no. The guest speakers were great, but Pachauri's presentations didn't really teach us anything new. I really appreciated being able to ask him the and guest speakers questions, although I wish he could have been a bit more candid with the class.
Yes
Yes
Yes, especially the lecturers´ participation.
I think it could be improved if there was more connection between the readings and the lectures.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes in that I was largely focused on the value of the final paper to allow me to research a topic I had an interest in.
Not even close.
Yes
Somewhat.
Yes. I am feeling very happy
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: No work group was conducted

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Have an idea for your term paper before you take this class...the content of the course willprobably not aid you in developing ideas. We had one workshopping day that was helpful to bounce ideas off of the TA and other classmates, but that was it.

Don't expect to be blown away by having Dr. Pachauri as a professor. In fact in some occasions he is just presenting material from IPCC reports that you will have probably seen many times before.Try to do some good background research on speakers, so as to askvaluable questions and possibly network with them.
Don't.
Be prepared to do background research on your own.
The speakers are interesting, but overall I didn't feel like the class lived up to the hype surrounding it.
They should be well prepared before the class then and then they can imbibe a lot.
I would advice them that this course is not as partipatory as other classes. As long as students understand that, then expectations would be better adjusted to reality.
